# Create a bar and line chart to visualize Valentine's Day spending trends over the years ggplot(historical_full_spending, aes(x = Year)) + # Add a bar chart to show the average per-person spending each year geom_bar( aes(y = PerPerson, text = paste0("Year: ", Year, "
Per Person Spend: $", round(PerPerson, 2))), # Add hover text for plotly stat = "identity", # Use identity to represent actual values fill = "hotpink", # Set bar color to hotpink alpha = 0.7 # Set transparency for the bars ) + # Add a line to represent total expected spending (scaled by 10 for visualization) geom_line( aes(y = total_expected_valentines_day_spending_in_billions * 10), # Scale total spending for better visualization color = "mediumvioletred", # Line color set to mediumvioletred size = 1 # Set line thickness ) + # Add points for each total expected spending data point geom_point( aes(y = total_expected_valentines_day_spending_in_billions * 10, # Match y value to scaled total spending text = paste0("Year: ", Year, "
Total Spend: $", total_expected_valentines_day_spending_in_billions, "B")), # Add hover text for plotly color = "mediumvioletred", # Set point color to match the line size = 2 # Set point size ) + # Add text labels above the total spending points for additional information geom_text( aes(y = total_expected_valentines_day_spending_in_billions * 10 + 10, # Adjust y position for text labels label = paste0("$", total_expected_valentines_day_spending_in_billions, "B")), # Show total spending in billions size = 3, # Set text size fontface = "bold" # Make text bold ) + # Add plot titles and axis labels labs( title = "Valentine's Day Spending Plans", # Set plot title x = "Year", # Set x-axis label y = "Spending ($)" # Set y-axis label ) + # Apply a minimal theme for a clean layout theme_minimal() + # Center the plot title and increase font size theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16)) + # Add manual annotations to represent legend information annotate("point", x = 2013.9, y = -12, color = "hotpink", size = 3) + # Add point for "Per Person Spend" annotate("text", x = 2015.1, y = -12, label = "Per Person Spend", size = 3, color = "black") + # Add label for "Per Person Spend" annotate("point", x = 2017, y = -12, color = "mediumvioletred", size = 3) + # Add point for "Total Spend" annotate("text", x = 2017.8, y = -12, label = "Total Spend", size = 3, color = "black") # Add label for "Total Spend"

what: Spending trends on gifts breaking down by age
title: Valentine's Day Spending Data
text: gifts_age dataset provides insights spending trends different age groups. , create line chart visualize gift preferences among different age groups.
code: # Reshape the 'gifts_age' data from wide to long format using pivot_longer # This converts columns 'Candy' to 'GiftCards' into a single 'GiftCategory' column # and their respective values into a 'Percentage' column gifts_age_long <- gifts_age %>%   pivot_longer(     cols = Candy:GiftCards,          # Specify columns to reshape     names_to = "GiftCategory",       # New column for gift categories     values_to = "Percentage"         # New column for spending percentages   )  # Create a line plot to visualize spending on different gift categories by age group ggplot(gifts_age_long, aes(x = Age, y = Percentage, color = GiftCategory, group = GiftCategory)) +      # Add a line for each gift category, grouped by age group   geom_line(size = 1) +      # Add points to indicate data points for each age group and gift category   geom_point(size = 2) +      # Add titles and labels to the plot   labs(     title = "Spending on Different Gifts By Age Group",  # Plot title     x = "Age Group",                                     # X-axis label     y = "Percentage (%)",                                # Y-axis label     color = "Gift Category"                              # Legend title   ) +      # Apply minimal theme for a clean look   theme_minimal() +      # Use a color palette for distinguishing different gift categories   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Accent")

title: Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Trends from 2010 to 2022
text: package contains comprehensive data Valentine’s Day spending trends past decade, provided National Retail Federation(NRF), surveyed consumers annually plan celebrate Valentine’s Day. includes datasets capture total expected spending, average spending per person, spending gift type, consumer-preferred gifts, broken age gender. package designed help users, especially retailers, analyze consumer behavior spending patterns Valentine’s Day. package provides following datasets: ?gift_age: Shows percentage spending different gift categories, broken age groups. ?gift_gender: Shows percentage spending different gift categories, broken gender. ?historical_full_spending: Provides total expected spending, average spending per person average spending per person different gifts 2010 2022. ?historical_gift_trends_percent_buying: Provides consumer trends gift-buying, showing percentage people buying specific gift categories years.
